Paul Pierce Holds onto Love for NBA Despite Retirement

Camped out in his Los Angeles home, Paul Pierce's television is frequently programmed to NBA games. While some retired players turn away from the sport that once commanded their lives, Pierce has stayed attuned to the league he played in for 19 seasons, hosting friends for marquee matchups and ordering piles of chicken wings. “I put in a big order because we usually got friends over, and we're watching some hoops.”

Pierce, who played for the Boston Celtics, Brooklyn Nets, Washington Wizards and LA Clippers throughout his career, has savored every avenue to remain connected to the sport, being part of the Showtime Basketball family after a run with ESPN. And with so much consternation from plenty of Pierce's fellow former players, taking to national broadcast and podcast platforms to lament certain elements of present-day NBA, a conversation with the Hall of Fame swingman was the perfect opportunity to better understand why so many of Pierce's brethren are willing to voice criticisms of the league they once inhabited.

"It’s been happening for a while, but it seems like it's reached a fever pitch now where there are so many former players sitting at desks across the national networks and there are so many podcasts such as yours," Pierce said.

"There's a difference between older players telling you that behind the scenes and Charles being on national TV and everyone kind of airing out dirty laundry on podcasts. When you have all these prominent voices killing the product, it creates this discourse online that things for the league aren’t going well. So it sparks interest either way."

Pierce will head to Houston next week for the first round of the NCAA tournament, watching games from inside a Buffalo Wild Wings alongside "All The Smoke" podcast hosts Stephen Jackson and Matt Barnes, plus two-time WNBA MVP A'Ja Wilson as part of an activation experience labeled "BnB-Dubs." He intends to not only watch the young talent on display, but also to bring his competitiveness to the table and add to the experience of watching with his friend group.

In fact, Pierce continues to see himself as a part of the sport in important ways. “I got a call from Marcus [Smart] on the day of the trade deadline, and he was like, 'Man, you always got Boston blood running through your veins.’ And I was like, 'Yeah, man, it's always going to be part of me," Pierce said.

He also thinks that his former team, the Celtics, has a bright future. "Jayson Tatum, Jaylen [Brown], they got some young players, they got some talent there, they got some draft picks," Pierce said. "They've taken that maturity leap to finally take that next step and possibly be together for a long time and win multiple championships if healthy."

Pierce, who racked up numerous awards and accolades during his career, including an NBA championship and Finals MVP in 2008, has been enjoying retirement thus far. Just recently, he reminisced about his draft night experience in 2013 during an interview with ESPN.

"I know it was 10 years ago now, but do you remember where you were on draft night 2013 when you got traded to Brooklyn?" he was asked.

"I was actually in LA, and I got the call 30 seconds before it was announced on TV," he replied.

Although he is clearly still involved in the basketball world, Pierce has also hinted at other projects he may be interested in taking on. Just last year, it was reported that he had joined the Showtime drama pilot “Hype,” which focuses on the rise of a young female rapper. Pierce also expressed interest in acting during an interview with The Athletic.

Regardless of which direction he chooses to take his career, it is clear that Pierce's love for the NBA and for competition will never fade away.
